data.name: MotivationA_Definition
data.value: This is a social and caring environment, where people get on well together. They co-operate and help each other. It is found in caring professions, charities and public services. It can also be present in some companies, for example in customer service departments.

data.name: MotivationA_Name
data.value: People Focused Environment

data.name: MotivationB_Definition
data.value: This type of environment is structured, predictable and with very clear requirements. It can be found in areas like administration and book-keeping where the emphasis is on order and high standards.

data.name: MotivationB_Name
data.value: Ordered Environment

data.name: MotivationC_Definition
data.value: This type of environment is competitive and lively, with an element of risk taking. People are valued for their ability to press for results and to achieve. It can often be found in sales roles.

data.name: MotivationC_Name
data.value: Lively Environment

data.name: MotivationD_Definition
data.value: This type of environment is creative and open to new ways of doing things. People who value this type of environment are likely to enjoy roles which are free of much of the conventions to do with work, e.g. how you look, how you behave etc.

data.name: MotivationD_Name
data.value: Creative Environment

data.name: MotivationE_Definition
data.value: This environment values “doers”: people who work hard and who enjoy having something to show for their efforts. These values tend to be reflected in work that is practical.

data.name: MotivationE_Name
data.value: Productive Environment

data.name: MotivationF_Definition
data.value: This environment is focused on specialist expertise. It suggests a role in a technical environment where people gain respect and reward on the basis of their expertise.

data.name: MotivationF_Name
data.value: Specialist Environment

data.name: MotivationG_Definition
data.value: This is an environment where the focus is on making money. Money is also given as a reward for doing well. It is typically found in commercial businesses rather than public sector or charity work.

data.name: MotivationG_Name
data.value: Money Focused Environment

data.name: PersonalStyle_ChallengeLeft
data.value: You may not enjoy persuading others. This means you may have to make an effort to convince potential employers that you have the skills needed to do the job.;#You are likely to be more reserved in groups. This may mean you need to practice being more open in assessment situations.;#;#;#You are less likely to enjoy looking at facts and figures. You may need to challenge yourself to look at data, as such information can be helpful when researching jobs.;#You have a tendency not to try to understand other people's behaviour. This means you may need to be more aware of how you can relate well to others in interviews.;#You are likely to be less open to new ways of doing things. This means you may need to make an effort to try different approaches when looking for work.;#You are likely to prefer a more flexible, less structured approach to looking for work. This means you may need to focus more on doing things in a systematic, organised way.;#You are likely to feel tense and worried when under pressure. Being aware of this and doing things to help you relax can make it easier for you to appear more confident in interviews or selection events.;#You are likely to show your emotions openly. Being aware of this can help you find ways to bounce back more quickly when things don't go your way, for example when a job application has been turned down.;#You are likely to prefer taking things steady and not being very busy. This means you may need to make an effort to take a more energetic, enthusiastic approach to looking for work.

data.name: PersonalStyle_ChallengeRight
data.value: ;#You tend to enjoy being around other people and may miss the company of others when looking for work.;#;#;#;#;#;#;#;#;#

data.name: PersonalStyle_DevelopmentLeft
data.value: Practice talking about your key strengths to a person you know. Ask them to question what you are saying and try to answer their questions.;#Try to talk more and be involved in conversations. Start off by doing this in situations you are more familiar with (for example, with people you know) and then try to do this when looking for work.;#;#;#List the three job options you are most interested in. For each of these find as much information based on facts as you can - for example, from employer websites.;#When meeting people who may want to employ you, try to understand what they are looking for and how they approach things.;#Try to use different ways of looking for work.You could use newspapers, magazines and a range of job websites, as well as people you know or your local job centre.;#Take care to get details right when filling in application forms. Double-check any application forms yourself or ask someone to help you with this. Pay attention to any deadlines for applications or other steps in the selection process. Leave enough time to complete all tasks required before the deadline.;#Find an approach that will help relax before a selection event. Relaxation techniques (for example breathing exercises), physical exercise or thinking positive thoughts can all be useful.;#It is natural to feel upset when things don't work out as you would like. However, try to keep calm and not get too upset by setbacks. Try to think of setbacks as an opportunity to learn.;#Set yourself specific goals for each day followed by a reward (for example today I will search three websites for jobs and make 5 applications before 5 o'clock and then I can relax this evening). This should help you keep going and allow you to achieve more in a shorter space of time.

data.name: PersonalStyle_DevelopmentRight
data.value: ;#Think about what you can do to find other people also looking for work, for example by going along to your local job centre. Try to find other sociable activities to be involved, for example, volunteering for a local community project.;#;#;#;#;#;#;#;#;#

data.name: PersonalStyle_RightNames
data.value: Persuasive,Sociable,Caring,Practical,Data Focused,Behavioural,Innovative,Structured,Tense,Emotionally Controlled,Energetic

data.name: PersonalStyle_StrengthMid
data.value: You may enjoy persuading others in some situations. This may help you sell your skills and make a strong impression with potential employers.;#You are likely to enjoy spending time with other people to some extent. This may help you to come across as friendly and sociable in assessment situations.;#;#;#You may enjoy looking at facts and figures. This could help you in researching different types of jobs.;#You may sometimes try to understand other people's behaviour. This could help you relate well to others in interviews.;#You may be open to doing things in new ways in some situations. This could help you to use a variety of different approaches when looking for work.;#You are may take a moderately organised approach looking for work. This can be helpful when filling in application forms or keeping track of applications.;#You may feel calm under pressure in some situations. This could help you to appear confident in interviews or selection events.;#You may keep emotions under control to some extent. This may help you bounce back when things don't go your way, for example when a job application has been turned down.;#You may enjoy keeping moderately busy. This could help you be energetic and maintain motivation when looking for work.

data.name: PersonalStyle_StrengthRight
data.value: You are likely to enjoy persuading others. This may help you sell your skills and make a strong impression with potential employers.;#You are likely to enjoy spending time with other people. This may help you to come across as friendly and sociable in assessment situations.;#;#;#You are likely to enjoy looking at facts and figures. This may help you in researching different types of jobs.;#Your tendency to try to understand other people's behaviour may help you relate well to others in interviews.;#Your openness to doing things in new ways is likely to help you to use a variety of different approaches when looking for work.;#You are likely to take a well organised approach looking for work. This can be especially helpful when filling in application forms or keeping track of applications.;#You are likely to feel calm under pressure. This may help you to appear confident in interviews or selection events.;#You are likely to keep your emotions under control. This may help you bounce back when things don't go your way, for example when a job application has been turned down.;#You are likely to enjoy keeping busy. This is likely to help you be energetic and maintain motivation when looking for work.

data.name: SkillsArea1_Definition
data.value: Takes responsibility for own actions and for leading others.

data.name: SkillsArea1_Description
data.value: take responsibility for your own actions, take control of situations and lead others.

data.name: SkillsArea1_DevelopmentTip1
data.value: Think of a time when you took responsibility for getting something done. Look at what went well and make a point of taking responsibility more often.

data.name: SkillsArea1_DevelopmentTip2
data.value: Next time you are in a situation which is unclear, be open about what you think. Clearly explain what you think should be done and why. Explain what you would like other people to do.

data.name: SkillsArea1_Name
data.value: Taking Responsibility

data.name: SkillsArea2_Definition
data.value: Works well with people by listening, understanding and helping others.

data.name: SkillsArea2_Description
data.value: work well with people, by listening, understanding and helping others.

data.name: SkillsArea2_DevelopmentTip1
data.value: Take time to notice when others have too much to do. Talk to them and offer to help them with some of their tasks.

data.name: SkillsArea2_DevelopmentTip2
data.value: Think more carefully about those around you. Speak less and listen more. Find out about their lives and issues. Put yourself in their shoes, imagine how they see themselves and how they see you.

data.name: SkillsArea2_Name
data.value: Working with Others

data.name: SkillsArea3_Definition
data.value: Convinces others and deals well with conflict. Expresses self clearly when speaking and writing.

data.name: SkillsArea3_Description
data.value: convince others, deal with conflict between people and express yourself clearly when speaking and writing.

data.name: SkillsArea3_DevelopmentTip1
data.value: When speaking with others, think about what other people are interested in as well as what you want to say. Use eye contact and positive body language to make others feel comfortable. Gather information to support your point of view. Speak slowly and clearly, to help others understand you.

data.name: SkillsArea3_DevelopmentTip2
data.value: If a disagreement starts, try to put yourself in the other person’s shoes before defending your point of view. Look at the disagreement as a difference of ideas or style, rather than of people. Try not to take sides and encourage others to do the same.

data.name: SkillsArea3_Name
data.value: Convincing and Communicating

data.name: SkillsArea4_Definition
data.value: Spots problems and gathers information, making judgements based on facts.

data.name: SkillsArea4_Description
data.value: spot problems, gather information and make judgements based on facts.

data.name: SkillsArea4_DevelopmentTip1
data.value: Think of a problem you have come across. Write down everything you know about the problem. Now look at what you have written down. Look for similarities. Can you group what you have written down? Are there any areas where you would benefit from having more information? Share this list with someone you trust.

data.name: SkillsArea4_DevelopmentTip2
data.value: Look back at some information that you collected to support a decision. Review this information, trying to pick it apart. Is the source trustworthy? Are there an gaps in this information? Is there anything in this information that you think could be wrong? Does this information cover different points of view?

data.name: SkillsArea4_Name
data.value: Solving Problems

data.name: SkillsArea5_Definition
data.value: Comes up with new ideas and different ways for approaching issues.

data.name: SkillsArea5_Description
data.value: come up with new ideas and different ways for approaching issues.

data.name: SkillsArea5_DevelopmentTip1
data.value: When you are next faced with an issue, list all the different ways in which this could be solved. Think of as many different ways as possible, try to fill a whole sheet of paper. Be creative and write all your ideas down. Try not to think about whether your ideas are good or bad, just come up with as many different ideas as possible. Once you have a long list, look back over it. Which of your ideas are similar? Which are different?

data.name: SkillsArea5_DevelopmentTip2
data.value: Try out new ways of doing things to see if you can find better ways for getting things done. Think of something that could be done better or improved. Rather than writing down your ideas, draw them. Draw how things are done now and draw how things could be done differently.

data.name: SkillsArea5_Name
data.value: Creative Thinking

data.name: SkillsArea5_Strength

data.name: SkillsArea6_Definition
data.value: Plans own tasks and uses time effectively to produce high quality work.

data.name: SkillsArea6_Description
data.value: plan and manage your own time, use your time effectively, focus on detail and produce high quality work.

data.name: SkillsArea6_DevelopmentTip1
data.value: Use lists and reminders to make sure you know what needs to get done. Keep a diary one week and see what you complete in that time and what gets put off. Set yourself doable daily tasks and stick to them.

data.name: SkillsArea6_DevelopmentTip2
data.value: Next time you are given a task to complete, leave some time at the end to check your work. Look back at your work: are there any mistakes, how can you make it better? Ask others for their advice and suggestions about how they check their own work.

data.name: SkillsArea6_Name
data.value: Planning and Focusing on Detail

data.name: SkillsArea7_Definition
data.value: Adapts to changes, remains calm and reacts positively to challenges.

data.name: SkillsArea7_Description
data.value: adapt to changes, remain calm under pressure and react positively to challenges.

data.name: SkillsArea7_DevelopmentTip1
data.value: Try to work out what causes you stress - think about situations recently where you felt stressed, what you were thinking and what you did. Think about what did and did not help. Think about what you can do next time to make the situation easier to handle.

data.name: SkillsArea7_DevelopmentTip2
data.value: Think about the good things that can come out of a changing situation. Think about how new experiences can give you new knowledge and understanding. Treat new challenges as exciting situations.

data.name: SkillsArea7_Name
data.value: Handling Change and Pressure

data.name: SkillsArea8_Definition
data.value: Shows energy and enthusiasm for meeting difficult goals and taking on new tasks.

data.name: SkillsArea8_Description
data.value: show energy and enthusiasm, work hard to meet difficult tasks and be keen to take on new tasks.

data.name: SkillsArea8_DevelopmentTip1
data.value: When you are next asked to do something for someone else, show them that you are excited to help. When you finish the task, ask them if there is anything else you can help with.

data.name: SkillsArea8_DevelopmentTip2
data.value: Next time you are given a task to do that you have never done before agree to do it. Think through what you need to do. Talk to other people who have done this before. Work hard to complete the task.

data.name: SkillsArea8_Name
data.value: Showing Energy and Drive

data.name: SkillsArea9_Definition
data.value: Easily learns new information and quickly learns how to use new technologies.

data.name: SkillsArea9_Description
data.value: learn new information easily and learn how to use new technologies quickly.

data.name: SkillsArea9_DevelopmentTip1
data.value: Find out what different things a computer can help you to do by using tutorials or setting yourself exercises that broaden your knowledge. Seek tips from others with more experience.

data.name: SkillsArea9_DevelopmentTip2
data.value: Think of a topic you are interested in but know little about. Use a computer to find out as much information as you can. Then ask a friend to test your knowledge on this topic.

data.name: SkillsArea9_Name
data.value: Learning and Technology
